<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
May/June 2017  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 320, 905, 335]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 502, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 361, 531]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 546]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 604, 570]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 759, 585]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 625, 91]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the density of water by two methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 203, 121]]<|/det|>
**Method 1**

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 128, 781, 725]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 737, 339, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[658, 738, 728, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 146, 788]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 768, 732, 789]]<|/det|>
Record the weight \(W_{1}\) of the piece of modelling clay shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 800, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<form>W_{1} = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 764, 89]]<|/det|>
The student lowers the modelling clay into the water, as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|>
• Record the new reading \(W_{2}\) of the forcemeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<form>W_2 = ............................................................ N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 170, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the measuring cylinder, with the piece of modelling clay in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 210, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<form>V_2 = ....................................................... cm^3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value \(\rho_{1}\) for the density of water, using your readings from **(a)**, **(b)** and **(c)** and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 291, 395, 329]]<|/det|>
\[\rho_{1} = \frac{(W_{1} - W_{2})}{(V_{2} - V_{1})}\times k\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 317, 357]]<|/det|>
where \(k = 100 \text{g} /\text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 402, 920, 421]]<|/det|>
<form>$\rho_{1} = ............................................................ [2]$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 205, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>Method 2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 144, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
The student removes the modelling clay from the water and places the measuring cylinder on a balance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 508, 608, 812]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 834, 534, 852]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 865, 861, 883]]<|/det|>
The reading for the mass \(m_{1}\) of the measuring cylinder and water is shown in Fig. 1.4.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 897, 420, 915]]<|/det|>
Record \(m_{1}\) to the nearest gram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 928, 920, 946]]<|/det|>
<form>m_1 = ............................................................ [1]

<form>0625/63/M/J/17

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 660, 91]]<|/det|>
Some students are investigating the resistance of a power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 479, 121]]<|/det|>
They are using the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 809, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 394, 532, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 144, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 426, 181, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 426, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
A student connects the crocodile clip to the resistance wire at positions which give particular values of the potential difference \(V\) between terminals \(\mathbf{P}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\). He measures the current \(I\) in the circuit for each position.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference \(V\) between terminals \(\mathbf{P}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 688, 91]]<|/det|> Fig. 2.2 shows the ammeter reading for a value of \(V = 2.2 \text{V}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 98, 648, 243]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 257, 534, 276]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 288, 569, 307]]<|/det|> Read, and record in Table 2.1, this value of \(I\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 320, 541, 337]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 346, 682, 530]]<|/det|>
\(I/\mathrm {A}\)\(V/\mathrm {V}\)
2.2
0.472.0
0.551.8
0.691.6
0.761.4
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 518, 920, 536]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 548, 146, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 548, 556, 567]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(I / \mathrm{A}\) (\(x\)-axis). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 574, 789, 922]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 633, 91]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(M\) of the line you have drawn.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 784, 121]]<|/det|>
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 197, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
<form>M = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 228, 181, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 228, 819, 247]]<|/det|>
The gradient \(M\) is numerically equal to the resistance \(R\) of the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 259, 918, 278]]<|/det|>
Write down the resistance \(R\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 305, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 148, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
Suggest one practical reason why the crocodile clip should not be connected to very short lengths of resistance wire in order to obtain smaller potential differences.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 144, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
In this type of experiment, it is possible to change the potential difference by using a variable resistor rather than using different lengths of a resistance wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 771, 542]]<|/det|>
In the space below, draw the standard circuit symbol for a variable resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 648, 920, 667]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 690, 89]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
She uses her results to determine a quantity known as the refractive index of the material of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 598, 152]]<|/det|>
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full size in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 170, 839, 870]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 917, 532, 935]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 947, 549, 960]]<|/det|>
0625/63/M/J/17

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The student places a transparent block ABCD at the centre of the ray-trace sheet, as indicated in Fig. 3.1. She draws round the block. She removes the block and then draws lines NL and EL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 576, 152]]<|/det|>
Measure the angle \(\theta\) between the lines NL and EL.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .....................................................[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line EL, a suitable distance apart for accurate ray-tracing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 571, 260]]<|/det|>
Suggest a suitable distance between the two pins.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ............................................................[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
The student replaces the block. She views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block from the direction indicated by the eye in position \(\mathbf{X}\) in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 920, 431]]<|/det|>
She labels the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and then removes the block and pins from the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 700, 462]]<|/det|>
She draws a line \(\mathbf{FG}\) through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), extending it as far as \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 183, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 710, 492]]<|/det|>
• Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{CD}\) at point \(\mathbf{G}\) and extend it to meet \(\mathbf{AB}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 500, 752, 518]]<|/det|>
• Label the point at which this normal meets \(\mathbf{AB}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 516, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 546, 181, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 546, 520, 564]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line joining points \(\mathbf{L}\) and \(\mathbf{G}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 572, 504, 590]]<|/det|>
• Extend line EL until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 725, 615]]<|/det|>
• Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{K}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 628, 500, 645]]<|/det|>
• Measure the length \(a\) of line \(\mathbf{LG}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 658, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
<form>a = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 689, 500, 707]]<|/det|>
• Measure the length \(b\) of line \(\mathbf{LK}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 719, 920, 737]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 735, 920, 752]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 766, 181, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 764, 763, 785]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value \(n\) for the refractive index, using the equation \(n = \frac{a}{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ............................................................[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The student places a mirror against side \(\mathbf{CD}\), with the reflecting surface facing towards the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
She views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in position \(\mathbf{Y}\) in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 920, 215]]<|/det|>
She labels the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) and then removes the mirror and the pins from the ray-trace.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 591, 245]]<|/det|>
The student draws a line \(\mathbf{RS}\) through pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 257, 504, 275]]<|/det|>
• Extend line \(\mathbf{RS}\) until it meets \(\mathbf{GH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 282, 724, 300]]<|/det|>
• Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{GH}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{T}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 308, 871, 325]]<|/det|>
• Measure the angle \(\alpha\), where \(\alpha\) is the smaller angle between lines \(\mathbf{RT}\) and \(\mathbf{GH}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
\[\alpha = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 384, 181, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 384, 883, 402]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) and angle \(\theta\), measured in part **(a)**, should be equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 415, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your answer with reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 463, 918, 480]]<|/det|>
statement ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
justification ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 144, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 920, 573]]<|/det|>
Suggest why different students, all carrying out this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 647, 920, 665]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how increasing the number of layers of insulation affects the rate of cooling of hot water in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 465, 136]]<|/det|>
Write a plan for the experiment, including:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 341, 168]]<|/det|>
· the apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 366, 200]]<|/det|>
· what you would measure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 214, 796, 231]]<|/det|>
· the variables you would keep the same to ensure the comparison is a fair test

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 245, 510, 262]]<|/det|>
· instructions for carrying out the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 276, 452, 293]]<|/det|>
· how you would present your results

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 307, 620, 324]]<|/det|>
· how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 337, 576, 355]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
